description:
This course encourages students to analyze the problems of managing the total enterprise in the domestic and international setting. The focus is on the competitive strategy of the firm, examining issues central to its long- and short-term competitive position. Students act in the roles of key decision-makers or their advisors and solve problems related to the development or maintenance of the competitive advantage of the firm in a given market. The first module of the course develops an understanding of key strategic frameworks using theoretical readings and case-based discussions. Students will learn concepts and tools for analyzing the competitive environment, strategic position and firm-specific capabilities in order to understand the sources of a firm's competitive advantage. In addition, students will address corporate strategy issues such as the economic logic and administrative challenges associated with diversification choices about horizontal and vertical integration. The second module will be conducted as a multi-session, computer-based simulation in which students will have the opportunity to apply the concepts and tools from module 1 to make strategic decisions. 

The goal of the course is for students to develop an analytical tool kit for understanding strategic issues and to enrich their appreciation for the thoughtprocesses essential to incisive strategic analysis. This course offers students the opportunity to develop a general management perspective by combining their knowledge of specific functional areas with an appreciation forthe requirements posed by the need to integrate all functions into a coherent whole. Students will develop skills in structuring and solving complex business problems.

values.comments:
Management 223 encourages students to analyze the problems of managing the total enterprise in the domestic and international setting. The focus is on the competitive strategy of the firm, examining issues central to its long- and short-term competitive position. Students act in the roles of key decision-makers or their advisors and solve problems related to the development or maintenance of the competitive advantage of the firm in a given market. The first module of the course develops an understanding of key strategic frameworks using theoretical readings and case-based discussions. Students learn concepts and tools for analyzing the competitive environment, strategic position, and firm-specific capabilities in order to understand the sources of a firm's competitive advantage. In addition, students address corporate strategy issues such as the economic logic and administrative challenges associated with diversification choices about horizontal and vertical integration. The second module is conducted as a multi-session, computer-based simulation in which students have the opportunity to apply the concepts and tools from module one to make strategic decisions. The goal of the course is for students to develop an analytical tool kit for understanding strategic issues and to enrich their appreciation for the thought processes essential to incisive strategic analysis. This course offers students the opportunity to develop a general management perspective by combining their knowledge of specific functional areas with an appreciation for the requirements posed by the need to integrate all functions into a coherent whole. The aim is for students to develop skills in structuring and solving complex business problems.

Overall, students “really enjoyed the course” and felt that it was “interesting,” that it “emphasize[d] core concepts well,” and that it was a “great class for anyone wanting to learn more about business strategy.” Students appreciated “interesting discussions” as well as “interesting material” and “useful and insightful” cases. However, there were mixed reviews about the computer-based simulation. A number described it as “difficult but very good and informative” while others thought it “was too time consuming” and said that they “would have rather focused on the real world.” One student wished that the class could have “gone deeper into the subject matter,” and another student would have preferred a more “structured approach.”

Students’ praise of Professor Chatain was universal and enthusiastic. He was described as “very articulate,” “very accessible,” “knowledgeable,” “wise,” and “very engaging.” One student described Professor Chatain as teaching “management from a deep intellectual perspective, challenging [students] to think in new ways,” and another said that he “did a great job communicating the subject matter and being available to help students.” A third student praised his appreciation for “innovative and out of the box thinking, rather than just fluff” and his ability to lead “an interesting discussion” and to “extract value from [students’] comments.” Unfortunately, Professor Chatain did not hold regular office hours and instead was only available by appointment.

One student observed that there was “quite a bit of reading required and cold calling in class” and a number of students mentioned a participation grade, which one student complained made “discussions too formal and intimidating to really enjoy simply for the love of learning.” One student summarized by saying that “the overall design of the course is good with evenly distributed coursework (as in the grades don’t all come at the end).” The prerequisites for the course are Management 100 and Management 101, and it is intended for juniors and seniors who have completed introductory courses in finance, marketing, and accounting. Management 223 is one of five core courses for the Management Concentration from which students concentrating in Management must select at least two. It can also fulfill a requirement for the Managing Electronic Commerce Concentration.
